UML:TaggedValue.value: The configuration package provides the tools to store configuration settings for your application. Configuration options are stored on disk using INI files. The configuration package supports manipulation and storage of INI files in addition to the possibility to override settings using the override system.
Jan Borsodi
Enterprise Architect XMI/UML 1.3
Jan Borsodi
Jan Borsodi
The validation is an error which means the configuration cannot be read, if tried an exception will be thrown.
Not Specified
The validation is a warning which means the configuration can be read but the configuration has some issues which the user could fix. Will only used when strict validation is enabled.
Not Specified
The type of validation problem, one of the TYPE_ERROR or TYPE_WARNING values.
Not Specified
The line number the error or warning occured on. If this is false the location is unknown. @note Line numbers start with 1.
Not Specified
The column number the error or warning occured on. If this is false the location is unknown. @note Column numbers start with 0.
Not Specified
The description of the error or warning which can be shown to the end user. @note The description should not contain the line or column number, instead set the properties.
Not Specified
Technical description of the error or warning which can be shown to the developer. @note The description should not contain the line or column number, instead set the properties.
Not Specified
Initialises the validation item with location information and description.
The type of item, use either TYPE_ERROR or TYPE_WARNING.
The line number the error or warning occured.
The column number the error or warning occured.
The description of the error or warning which can be shown to the end user.
Technical description of the error or warning which can be shown to the developer.
Source -> Destination

This class provides the functionality for writing file based configuration formats.
This class implements most of the interface of ezcConfigurationWriter and makes it easier to work on file based configuration. All methods except save() are implemented by this class so a subclass only needs to handle the actual serialization.
Jan Borsodi
The path to the file which will contain the serialized configuration data. @note If this property is modified the location, name and suffix will be modified too.
Not Specified
Not Specified
The current location of the config, this is either the path on the filesystem or a PHP stream prefix.
Not Specified
The base name of the configuration file, the suffix will be appended to this to find the real filename.
Not Specified
Current options for the writer. @note See the specific writer to see which options it supports.
Not Specified
Not Specified
Constructs the writer and intialises it with the file to write and the file permission to use. After construction call save() to create the INI file on disk.
The relative or absolute path to where the configuration should be stored. Using PHP streams is also possible, e.g. gzip:site.ini.gz
The permission to use when creating the INI file, this value is an integer and can be created by using the decoct() function. Pass a value of false if you don't want to modify the permission value.
The configuration object to write as an INI file or false to specify the object at a later time.
Initialises the writer with a location and a name. These values determine where the configuration will be serialized.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: The current configuration object which should be serialized by the current writer.
The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
An associative array of options for the writer. Which options to use is determined by the specific writer class.
Returns the current configuration object if one is set, false otherwise.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Sets the current configuration object to be used for storage with save(). @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: The current configuration object which should be serialized by the current writer. Use false if you wish to remove the current configuration object.
Return the current location string.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Sets the current location where the configuration will be written. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.
Return the current name for the configuration to be written.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Sets the current name of the configuration to be written. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
Returns the current options for the writer.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Sets the current options for the writer. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: An associative array of options for the writer. Which options to use is determined by the specific writer class.
Source -> Destination
Source -> Destination

$XREFPROP=$XID={2BDA846C-0004-4d14-8D5A-DB95AA249EA0}$XID;$NAM=CustomProperties$NAM;$TYP=connector property$TYP;$VIS=Public$VIS;$DES=@PROP=@NAME=isSubstitutable@ENDNAME;@TYPE=boolean@ENDTYPE;@VALU=@ENDVALU;@PRMT=@ENDPRMT;@ENDPROP;$DES;$CLT={F28A6AB9-BA73-40ea-89CE-20949231B5A1}$CLT;$SUP=<none>$SUP;$ENDXREF;

Jan Borsodi
Jan Borsodi
Jan Borsodi

Holds information on whether the validation process was a success or not, will be true if successful and false if unsuccessful.
@note The validation process will determine when a configuration is valid, for instance if a stricter validation is run it will set it as invalid even if it contains warnings.
Not Specified
A count on how many error items the validation process resulted in. The error items can be accessed by traveresing $resultList.
Not Specified
A count on how many warning items the validation process resulted in. The warning items can be accessed by traveresing $resultList.
Not Specified
Contains an array with ezcConfigurationValidationItem objects which are either errors or warnings detected during the validation process.
Not Specified
The location of the configuration which was validated.
Not Specified
The name of the configuration which was validated.
Not Specified
Similar to $name and $location but is generated by the specific reader and contain more readable information to the end user.
Not Specified
Initialises the validation result with some information on the configuration file and an empty result list.
The main placement for the configuration as returned by the reader.
The name for the configuration as returned by the reader.
A displayable name for the configuration which is made by the reader.
Creates an ezcConfigurationValidationItem of the parameters and appends it to the result list. @see appendItem()
The type of item, use either TYPE_ERROR or TYPE_WARNING.
The line number the error or warning occured.
The column number the error or warning occured.
The description of the error or warning which can be shown to the end user.
Technical description of the error or warning which can be shown to the developer.
Appends the validation item to the result list. @see appendResult()
The error or warning item which should be added to the end of the result list.
Source -> Destination
Source -> Destination
Jan Borsodi

This class provides the functionality for reading file based configuration formats.
This class implements most of the interface of ezcConfigurationReader and makes it easier to work on file based configuration. All methods except load() and validate() are implemented by this class, so a subclass only needs to handle the actual serialization.
Jan Borsodi
The path to the file which will contain the serialized configuration data. @note If this property is modified the location, name and suffix will be modified too.
Not Specified
The current location of the config, this is either the path on the filesystem or a PHP stream prefix.
Not Specified
The base name of the configuration file, the suffix will be appended to this to find the real filename.
Not Specified
Current options for the reader. @note See the specific reader to see which options it supports.
Not Specified
Not Specified
Constructs the writer and intialises it with the file to write and the file permission to use. After construction call save() to create the INI file on disk.
The relative or absolute path to where the configuration should be stored. Using PHP streams is also possible, e.g. gzip:site.ini.gz
Initialises the writer with a location and a name. These values determine where the configuration will be serialized.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: The current configuration object which should be serialized by the current writer.
The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
An associative array of options for the writer. Which options to use is determined by the specific writer class.
Returns the current configuration object if one is set, false otherwise. The object will be set each time load() is called.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Checks if the configuration exists at the given location and returns true or false. @retval bool

Identifies the interface operation

Identifies the interface operation

Identifies the interface operation

Jan Borsodi
Initialises the writer with a location and a name. These values determine where the configuration will be serialized.
The current configuration object which should be serialized by the current writer.
The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
An associative array of options for the writer. Which options to use is determined by the specific writer class.
Returns the current configuration object if one is set, false otherwise. The object will be set each time load() is called.
Checks if the configuration exists at the given location and returns true or false. @retval bool
Returns the last modified timestamp of the configuration or false if it does not exist.
Return the current location string.
Sets the current location where the configuration will be written. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.
The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.
Return the current name for the configuration to be written.
Sets the current name of the configuration to be written. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
Returns the current options for the writer.
Sets the current options for the writer. @note This will only be used the next time save() is called.
An associative array of options for the writer. Which options to use is determined by the specific writer class.
Validates the configuration at the given location and returns the validation result.
Controls how strict the validation is. If set to true it will not validate the file if it contains any errors or warnings. If false it will allow warnings but not errors.
Jan Borsodi

The array reader/writer can be used for simple caching of config objects.
Jan Borsodi
Jan Borsodi
The main location of the configurations which is passed to each reader, this is either the path on the filesystem or a PHP stream prefix.
Not Specified
Options for the readers, this is passed on when the reader is created for the first time. @note See the specific reader to see which options it supports.
Not Specified
The name of the class to create readers from. This class must implement the ezcConfigurationReader interface, if not an exception is thrown when it is created.
Not Specified
Maps the name of the configuration to the ezcConfiguration object.
Not Specified
Maps the name of the configuration to the cached ezcConfiguration object.
Not Specified
Initializes the manager. @note Private constructor to avoid creating more than one instance, use getInstance() to get the object instance.

Returns the unique global instance of the manager.
To configure the manager a call to init() must be done at the start of the application.
Initialise the manager with the values which will be used by the configuration reader. It sets the default location and reader options and which reader to use by specifying the class name.
The main placement for the configuration. It is up to the specific reader to interpret this value. This can for instance be used to determine the directory location for an INI file.
The name of the class to use as a configuration reader. @note This class must implement the ezcConfigurationReader interface.
Options for the configuration reader, this is passed on the reader specified in $readerClass when it is created. Check the documentation for the specific reader to see which options it supports.
Returns true if the specified setting exists in the specified configuration.
The name of the setting to find.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
The name of the setting to find.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
The names of the settings to find.
The name of the group the settings will be located in.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.
Checks if the setting named $name exists using the current configuration reader and return true or false.

The name for the configuration. It is up to the specific writer to interpret this value. This can for instance be the basename for the INI file, so a value of 'site' would create a file with name 'site.ini'.

Jan Borsodi
Contains all the setting groups in the configuration, the name of the group is the key and the value is the settings array.
Not Specified
Contains all the comments that exist for the configuration. The structure of the comments array is the same as the $groups array but will only contain entries for settings which have comments.
Not Specified
Not Specified
Intialises the configuration object with the groups and the comments.
Array containing all the groups and their settings with values can be used to initialise the configuration from a read file.
Comments for the groups.
Comments for the settings.
Returns true if the specified setting exists.
The name of the setting to find.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.
The name of the setting to find.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.
Sets the specified setting to $value. If the setting does not already exists it will be created.
The value of the setting, can be any PHP type.
The name of the setting to set.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.
The name of the setting to remove.
The name of the group the setting will be located in.
Return true if all the specified settings exists.
The names of the settings to find.
The name of the group the settings will be located in.
The names of the settings to find.
The name of the group the settings will be located in.
Sets the specified settings to the values in the array $values. If the settings does not already exists it will be created.
The names of the settings to set.
The name of the group the settings will be located in.
The names of the settings to remove.
The name of the group the settings will be located in.
Return the names of all the groups as an array.
Return true if the specified group exists.
The name of the group to find.
Returns the names of all settings in the specified group as an array. @throw ezcConfigurationException::UNKNOWN_GROUP if the group does not exist.
Returns all settings in the specified group. @throw ezcConfigurationException::UNKNOWN_GROUP if the group does not exist.
The name of the group to find settings in.
Removes the specified group from the settings. @throw ezcConfigurationException::UNKNOWN_GROUP if the group does not exist.
The name of the group to remove.

Return all the groups and their settings and values as an array. The returned array looks like: array( 'group1' => array( 'setting1' => 'value1', 'setting2' => 'value2' ), 'group2' => array( 'setting3' => 'value3' ) );
Removes all groups, settings, values and comments.
Sets the options for the configuration object.
Array of options to set.
Returns the current options for the configuration object.
Return true if the configuration has been modified since it was initialised with the constructor.

This class provides an exception for errors occuring while accessing file based configurations. Create the exception and pass the error code in the constructor, the error message will be automatically created. throw new ezcConfigurationFileException( ezcConfigurationFileException::FILE_NOT_READABLE );
Jan Borsodi
The configuration file could not be found on the filesystem.
Not Specified
The configuration file could not be read from the filesystem.
Not Specified
The configuration file could not be written to the filesystem.
Not Specified
Creates the exceptions with one of the class constants as error code. The error message will be generated automatically from the code.
The error code which is taken from one of the class constants.
Source -> Destination

This class provides an exception for errors occuring while parsing, loading and accessing configurations. Create the exception and pass the error code in the constructor, the error message will be automatically created. throw new ezcConfigurationException( ezcConfigurationException::NO_CONFIG );
Jan Borsodi
No configuration object has been set to operate on. The operation cannot continue with this object.
Not Specified
The current location is not valid. This means it is impossible to read or write using the location values.
Not Specified
No config object is present to work on. Cannot continue operation.
Not Specified
The read operation for the configuration failed.
Not Specified
The write operation for the configuration failed.
Not Specified
The specified group does not exist in the settings.
Not Specified
The specified setting does not exist in the settings.
Not Specified
The specified configuration does not exist in the system.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not a boolean which was the requested type.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not an integer which was the requested type.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not a float which was the requested type.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not a number which was the requested type.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not a string which was the requested type.
Not Specified
The accessed setting is not an array which was the requested type.
Not Specified
Creates the exceptions with one of the class constants as error code. The error message will be generated automatically from the code.
The error code which is taken from one of the class constants.

The relative or absolute path to where the configuration should be read from. Using PHP streams is also possible, e.g. gzip:site.ini.gz

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Returns the last modified timestamp of the configuration or false if it does not exist.

UML:Comment.name: Qualified name for the interface operation
Identifies the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Validates the configuration at the given location and returns the validation result.

UML:Comment.name: Identifies the interface operation
Qualified name for the interface operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Controls how strict the validation is. If set to true it will not validate the file if it contains any errors or warnings. If false it will allow warnings but not errors.
